title: Do incurable disabling illnesses that caused me to close my business help me with chapter 7 bankruptcy?
question: When a rare illness with multiple underlying incurable conditions caused me to become so ill that I could no longer work and therefore, close my business (sole proprietorship, dance studio). When it comes to filing chapter 7 bankruptcy, does the fact that disabling conditions caused my inability to work play any part in filing bankruptcy? (For example, are there certain parts of the application process, such as being excused from repaying a certain person or creditor, that are made easier/automatically "forgiven" with proper documentation of my disability?
answers:
Your petition schedules and related documents allow you to tell the Trustee your story. If you have medical bills then these will show up on your liabilities schedule. If you are no longer working then this will show up on your income and expense schedules. I have found that each client's set of circumstances are different.
The bankruptcy laws are there to help the honest but unfortunate debtor, of which you certainly are. You shouldn't feel guilty because circumstances outside of your control caused you to seek the relief.

Filing for bankruptcy protection does not require completing forms "explaining" why you are seeking this legal remedy. That said, facts related to your illness, such as lowered/lost income, increased healthcare & medical costs, business related debt, etc. may help, depending.

Correctly filing bankruptcy involves multiple levels of analysis, possibly a wide variety of pitfalls, and many interconnected parts. Certainly this area of law if not best suited for ambitious DIY (do-it-yourself) folks.

Bottom line: You would be wise to look for help from an experienced bankruptcy lawyer.
your disability may help you with the amount of homestead exemption you can claim and your income qualification for the means test. See an experienced bankruptcy attorney for details.
No your illness has no bearing on your chapter 7 filing. You should consult with a local experienced bankruptcy attorney. Most offer free consultations.

No, your illness will not likely play any relevant part in the bankruptcy process. Your motive/reason for filing is generally not a factor. Unsecured debts are discharged w/o reference to your illness. The standard for a creditor who objects to discharge of its debt does not have a higher burden of proof because of your illness. BK is not a DIY project. Get a good lawyer to assist you. Some Avvo lawyers offer a free consultation by phone or in person.
No, it will not make a difference (except possibly if you try to discharge student loans).
